title: Make Your Bed
description: Start the day by making your bed look neat and tidy.
steps: 1. Stand at the foot of your bed|2. Pull the duvet or blankets up toward the pillow|3. Straighten the sides so they hang evenly|4. Fluff and place your pillow neatly|5. Step back and check it looks tidy
goal: Building a morning habit and a sense of order
success: Your bed looks neat with no duvet hanging on the floor

title: Eat a Real Breakfast
description: Eat a proper breakfast before school or any activity.
steps: 1. Choose something that includes protein or complex carbs — eggs, toast, porridge, yoghurt, cereal|2. Make sure you have a drink — water or milk|3. Sit down and eat without screens|4. When finished, rinse your bowl or plate
materials: cereal or bread or other food, bowl, spoon, drink
goal: Fuelling your brain and body for the day
success: You have eaten a full breakfast sitting down

title: Drink a Glass of Water First
description: Before anything else, drink a full glass of water when you wake up.
steps: 1. Go to the kitchen|2. Fill a glass with water|3. Drink all of it before you eat or check your phone|4. Notice how your body feels afterward
success: You have drunk a full glass of water before doing anything else

title: Get Dressed Before Screens
description: Get fully dressed and ready before looking at any screens.
steps: 1. When you wake up, go straight to get dressed|2. Put on clean clothes including socks and shoes if needed|3. Check you have everything you need|4. Only then can you check your phone or TV
goal: Building self-discipline and a reliable morning sequence
success: You are fully dressed including shoes before touching any screen

title: Write Down Your Top 3 Today
description: Each morning, write down three things you want to do or remember today.
steps: 1. Get your notebook or a piece of paper|2. Write today's date at the top|3. Write down three things — one thing you must do, one you want to do, one you are looking forward to|4. Keep the paper somewhere you can see it during the day
materials: notebook or paper, pen or pencil
success: You have written three clear things for today in your own words

title: 5-Minute Stretch or Walk
description: Before sitting down to work or school, do 5 minutes of gentle movement.
steps: 1. Find a clear space|2. Roll your shoulders backward 5 times|3. Reach both arms above your head and hold for 5 seconds|4. Do 10 slow neck rolls, 5 each direction|5. March on the spot for 1 minute|6. Touch your toes or reach as far as you can, hold for 10 seconds
goal: Getting your body and brain awake and energised
success: You have done all five movements without rushing

title: Tidy Your Bedroom in 5 Minutes
description: Do a quick 5-minute tidy of your bedroom to start the day clear.
steps: 1. Set a timer for 5 minutes|2. Put any clothes on the floor either in the laundry or folded away|3. Put books, bags or devices where they belong|4. Clear your desk if you have one|5. Stop when the timer goes, even if not perfect
goal: Creating an ordered space that helps your brain feel calm
success: Clothes are off the floor and things are generally in their right place

title: Pack Your School Bag the Night Before
description: Get your bag fully packed before you go to bed so mornings are calm.
steps: 1. Check your timetable or homework diary for tomorrow|2. Find every book, folder or item you need|3. Pack them one by one into your bag|4. Add your packed lunch or lunch money if needed|5. Put your bag by the door so it is ready to grab
success: Your bag is fully packed and by the door before bedtime

title: Check Homework is Complete
description: Before school, double-check that all homework due today is finished and in your bag.
steps: 1. Look at your planner or diary|2. Check every subject due today|3. Find each piece of homework and read it through quickly|4. Put it in your bag or folder|5. If something is not done, tell a trusted adult now rather than later
success: You have checked all homework and either it is done or you have told someone it is not

title: Sort Your Desk Before You Study
description: Clear and organise your workspace before starting any school work.
steps: 1. Clear everything off your desk|2. Put away anything that does not belong there|3. Get out only what you need for this work|4. Make sure you have a pen, pencil and any books you need|5. Sit down and start
materials: desk or table, pens, books needed
success: Your desk has only what you need for the task in front of you

title: Prepare Your PE Kit
description: Check and prepare your PE kit the night before a PE day.
steps: 1. Check your timetable to confirm you have PE tomorrow|2. Find your PE shorts, top and trainers|3. Make sure they are clean enough|4. Pack them in a bag inside or alongside your school bag|5. Check if you need anything else like a water bottle or tie-back for hair
success: PE kit is packed and ready the evening before PE day

title: Write Down All Homework Given Today
description: At the end of the school day, write down every piece of homework set.
steps: 1. Before leaving school, open your planner or notebook|2. Write the subject and the task for each piece of homework|3. Write the date it is due|4. Check the list makes sense and you understand each task|5. Bring it home
success: Every piece of homework set today is written down with its due date

title: Pomodoro Study Session
description: Study using timed focused blocks with short breaks in between.
steps: 1. Choose one task or subject to work on|2. Set a timer for 20 minutes|3. Work only on that task until the timer goes — no phone, no other tabs|4. When the timer goes, take a 5-minute break (walk, stretch, drink water)|5. Repeat two or three times
materials: timer, books or device for work, water
goal: Building focused work habits and avoiding burnout
success: You completed 2–3 work blocks without picking up your phone during them

title: Phone-Free Homework Block
description: Do all your homework with your phone in another room.
steps: 1. Collect everything you need for homework|2. Put your phone in another room or give it to a parent|3. Work through your homework without checking it|4. When homework is done, get your phone back|5. Notice how differently it felt
goal: Building deep focus and reducing dependency on phones
success: All homework is complete and you did not check your phone once during the session

title: One-Thing-at-a-Time Rule
description: Choose one single task and work on it until it is finished before starting anything else.
steps: 1. Look at your list of things to do|2. Choose the most important one|3. Work on ONLY that task — do not switch|4. When it is fully finished, cross it off|5. Only then choose the next task
success: You completed one full task without switching to anything else partway through

title: Read for 15 Minutes
description: Read a book — not a screen — for 15 minutes without stopping.
steps: 1. Choose a physical book or magazine|2. Find a comfortable and quiet place to sit|3. Set a timer for 15 minutes|4. Read continuously until the timer goes|5. If your mind wanders, gently bring it back to the page
success: You read for the full 15 minutes without stopping or switching to a screen

title: Plan Tomorrow the Night Before
description: Spend 5 minutes planning what you will do tomorrow so you are not starting from scratch in the morning.
steps: 1. Get a notebook or piece of paper|2. Write tomorrow's date|3. Write any fixed events like school, activities|4. Write 2–3 things you want to get done|5. Put the list somewhere you will see it in the morning
success: You have a written plan for tomorrow with at least 2 specific things on it

title: Distraction Dump
description: Before a study session, write down every distracting thought in your head so your brain can let go of it.
steps: 1. Get a piece of paper|2. Set a timer for 3 minutes|3. Write down every thought that is in your head — worries, things you want to do, things you remembered|4. When the timer goes, fold the paper and put it aside|5. Now start your work
goal: Clearing mental clutter before focused work
success: Your mind feels clearer and you were able to start working more easily

title: Feelings Check-In
description: Stop and ask yourself how you are feeling right now and name it.
steps: 1. Stop what you are doing and take one slow breath|2. Ask yourself: what am I feeling right now?|3. Try to name the feeling — not just good or bad but a real emotion word|4. Ask yourself: where do I feel it in my body?|5. Write it down or just notice it without judging it
materials: none — or journal if you have one
success: You have named at least one specific feeling and noticed where it lives in your body

title: Box Breathing
description: Use box breathing to calm your body and mind when you feel stressed or overwhelmed.
steps: 1. Sit up straight and close your eyes if comfortable|2. Breathe in slowly through your nose for 4 counts|3. Hold your breath for 4 counts|4. Breathe out slowly through your mouth for 4 counts|5. Hold empty for 4 counts|6. Repeat 4 times
goal: Activating calm, managing anxiety or stress
success: You completed 4 full rounds of box breathing and your body feels slightly calmer

title: Write in a Feelings Journal
description: Write freely about how you are feeling without worrying about spelling or anyone reading it.
steps: 1. Get a notebook|2. Write today's date|3. Write for at least 5 minutes about how you are feeling and why|4. Do not correct yourself — just write whatever comes|5. When done, close the journal. You do not need to read it back
success: You wrote for at least 5 full minutes without stopping

title: Do Something Kind Without Being Asked
description: Choose one kind action today and do it without anyone asking you to.
steps: 1. Think of one person in your life who might appreciate something|2. Choose a small action — make them a drink, tidy something for them, write a note, share something|3. Do it without telling everyone about it|4. Notice how you feel afterward
success: You did one kind action completely unprompted and without expecting anything back

title: Worry Time
description: Set aside 10 minutes just for worrying so your worries do not follow you all day.
steps: 1. Choose a specific time — not too close to bedtime|2. Set a timer for 10 minutes|3. Write down every worry on paper — all of it, big and small|4. For each worry, write: is there something I can do? If yes, write one small step|5. When the timer goes, close the notebook. Worry time is over until tomorrow
goal: Managing anxiety, separating worry from productive thinking
success: You spent a timed 10 minutes on worries and identified at least one actionable step

title: 5-4-3-2-1 Grounding
description: Use your five senses to pull your attention into the present moment when you feel overwhelmed.
steps: 1. Stop and sit somewhere comfortable|2. Name 5 things you can SEE right now|3. Name 4 things you can physically TOUCH|4. Name 3 things you can HEAR|5. Name 2 things you can SMELL|6. Name 1 thing you can TASTE
goal: Grounding, managing overwhelm, using senses to regulate
success: You worked through all five senses without rushing

title: Self-Compassion Moment
description: Talk to yourself the way you would talk to a good friend who is having a hard time.
steps: 1. Think of something that is bothering you right now|2. Imagine your best friend told you the same thing — what would you say to them?|3. Write or say those same words to yourself|4. Notice the difference between how you talk to a friend and how you talk to yourself
goal: Building self-compassion and reducing harsh self-talk
success: You wrote or said something genuinely kind to yourself that you would say to a friend

title: Send a Kindness Message
description: Send a message to someone to let them know you are thinking of them.
steps: 1. Think of someone you have not spoken to in a while or who might need cheering up|2. Write a genuine message — not just hey|3. Include something specific, like why you thought of them or a memory|4. Send it without expecting a reply
materials: phone or paper for a letter
goal: Staying connected, showing people they matter
success: You sent a genuine message with at least one specific thing in it

title: Introduce Yourself to Someone New
description: Practise introducing yourself to someone you do not know well.
steps: 1. Choose someone at school or in your community you have not spoken to before|2. Make eye contact and smile|3. Say hello and your name|4. Ask them one question to get them talking — What year are you in? How long have you been coming here?|5. Listen properly to their answer
success: You introduced yourself and had even a short real conversation

title: Write a Thank-You Note
description: Write a handwritten thank-you note to someone who has helped you.
steps: 1. Think of someone who has done something kind or helpful for you recently|2. Get paper and a pen|3. Write their name, say thank you and specifically say what they did and why it mattered|4. Sign your name|5. Give it to them or leave it somewhere they will find it
goal: Gratitude, manners in action, written communication
success: You wrote a genuine thank-you note with a specific reason and gave it to them

title: Active Listening Practice
description: Have a conversation where your only job is to listen — no advice, no your-turn stories, just listening.
steps: 1. Ask someone how their day was or how they are feeling|2. When they talk, give them your full attention — no phone, no planning what you will say|3. Ask one follow-up question based on what they said|4. Do not share your own story unless they ask|5. When the conversation ends, notice how they seem
success: You had a full conversation where you asked at least one real follow-up question and did not redirect to yourself

title: Apologise Properly
description: Practise giving a genuine apology for something you did that affected someone else.
steps: 1. Think of something you did recently that might have upset or inconvenienced someone|2. Do not wait for them to bring it up|3. Find a quiet moment|4. Say: I am sorry for [specific thing]. I know it must have felt [how they might have felt]. I will try to [what you will do differently]|5. Do not follow the apology with a but
success: You gave an apology that included a specific action, an acknowledgement of feeling, and no excuses

title: Hold the Door, Smile and Say Thanks
description: Every time someone does something small for you today, say thank you with eye contact.
steps: 1. Today, notice every time someone does something for you — holds a door, lets you past, gives you something|2. Each time, make eye contact and say thank you clearly|3. Count how many times you do this|4. At the end of the day, notice how it felt
goal: Building the habit of noticing and appreciating small acts
success: You said a clear, genuine thank you at least 5 times during the day

title: Help With One Household Job
description: Choose one household job and do it completely without being asked.
steps: 1. Look around your home and find something that needs doing — dishes, tidying, vacuuming, putting things away|2. Do it fully, not halfway|3. Do not tell everyone or wait for thanks — just do it|4. Notice how the space looks when it is done
goal: Contribution, responsibility, being part of a team
success: The job is completely finished without being asked and without seeking praise

title: Prepare Tomorrow's Outfit
description: Choose and set out the clothes you will wear tomorrow before you go to bed.
steps: 1. Think about what you are doing tomorrow — school, sport, casual|2. Choose a full outfit including socks and underwear|3. Put it out on a chair or the end of your bed|4. Check it is clean and nothing needs washing or ironing
success: A complete outfit including all items is laid out and ready for tomorrow

title: Screen-Free Wind-Down
description: Spend 30 minutes before bed without any screens.
steps: 1. At your chosen wind-down time, put your phone or device in another room or give it to a parent|2. Choose a calm activity — reading, colouring, stretching, writing, quiet music|3. Do this for 30 minutes|4. Notice how quickly you feel sleepy compared to nights when you stay on screens
materials: physical book, notebook, or nothing — no phone
goal: Sleep hygiene, helping your brain switch off
success: You spent 30 minutes before bed doing something calm with no screens

title: Tidy Your Study Space for Tomorrow
description: Clear your desk or work area at the end of the day so you can start fresh tomorrow.
steps: 1. Put away all books and stationery|2. Clear any rubbish and put it in the bin|3. Straighten any piles|4. Put your school bag in the right place|5. Take one moment to look at it — a clear space for tomorrow
goal: Creating good end-of-day habits and a calm environment
success: Your desk or work area is clear and organised for tomorrow

title: Gratitude List
description: Before sleep, write down three things from today that you are grateful for.
steps: 1. Get your journal or a piece of paper|2. Write today's date|3. Write three things that happened today that you feel good about, however small|4. They do not have to be big — a nice conversation, food you enjoyed, something that made you laugh|5. Read them back once before putting the light out
goal: Gratitude, positive thinking, ending the day well
success: You have written three specific things — not just generic words like family

title: Check Tomorrow's Timetable
description: Look at what you have on tomorrow so there are no surprises in the morning.
steps: 1. Open your school planner, diary or check with a parent|2. Look at tomorrow's lessons or activities|3. Check if there is anything you need to prepare — PE kit, ingredients, a specific book|4. Sort anything that needs sorting now
success: You know exactly what is on tomorrow and anything that needs preparing is sorted

title: Phone Charging Spot Outside Bedroom
description: Charge your phone or device somewhere other than your bedroom tonight.
steps: 1. Tell yourself this is the plan before you get tired and find it harder|2. Plug your phone in to charge in the kitchen, hallway or another room|3. Do not bring it back into your bedroom|4. If you use your phone as an alarm, use a separate alarm clock or set your alarm before leaving it to charge
materials: phone charger, separate alarm clock if needed
goal: Sleep hygiene, better quality rest, reducing morning temptation
success: Your phone charged outside your bedroom and you fell asleep without it

title: Full Body Relaxation Scan
description: Do a head-to-toe relaxation exercise to help your body settle before sleep.
steps: 1. Lie down in bed|2. Starting with your feet, squeeze all the muscles in your feet tightly for 3 seconds, then let go|3. Move up to your calves, thighs, stomach, hands, shoulders and finally your face|4. Each time, squeeze for 3 seconds then completely let go|5. When you reach your face, take 3 slow breaths
goal: Deep physical relaxation and sleep preparation
success: Your whole body feels noticeably heavier and more relaxed than when you started

title: Write One Thing You Learned Today
description: Before bed, write one thing you genuinely learned or noticed today.
steps: 1. Get your journal|2. Think back over the day|3. Write one thing that you did not know before today — a fact, something about yourself, something about someone else|4. Write why it matters or what you will do with it
goal: Reflection, curiosity, building a learning habit
success: You have written one specific thing you learned and at least one sentence about why it matters

title: Declutter One Small Area
description: Choose one drawer, shelf or surface and sort through it properly.
steps: 1. Choose ONE small area — not a whole room|2. Take everything out|3. Make three piles: keep, throw away, belongs somewhere else|4. Throw the rubbish pile away|5. Put the somewhere-else things where they belong|6. Put the keep things back neatly
success: The chosen area is clear, tidy and you know what is in it

title: Create a Weekly Routine Chart
description: Make a chart of your regular weekly tasks and activities.
steps: 1. Get a piece of paper or a notebook|2. Write the days of the week across the top|3. For each day, write any fixed events: school, activities, clubs|4. Add recurring tasks: homework, chores, reading|5. Put the chart somewhere visible in your room
goal: Planning, self-management, knowing what your week looks like
success: You have a completed weekly chart that is accurate for your current week

title: Label Your School Stuff
description: Label all your school equipment, books and bags with your name.
steps: 1. Collect all your school things|2. Write your name clearly on every book, folder and loose item|3. Put a name label or sticker on your bag|4. Make sure your PE kit has your name on it somewhere|5. Check if your water bottle is labelled
materials: name stickers or a permanent marker, school things
success: Everything you take to school has your name on it

title: Set Up a Homework Spot
description: Create a dedicated place where you always do homework.
steps: 1. Choose a space — a desk, kitchen table or quiet area|2. Make sure it has good light|3. Clear it of anything that is not for work|4. Add what you need: pens, ruler, notebook, somewhere to put your water|5. Use this spot every day for homework
materials: desk or table, lamp if needed, stationery
goal: Creating a physical environment that supports focus
success: You have set up a consistent homework spot you used for a full session today

title: Sort Your School Bag
description: Empty and reorganise your school bag so you know exactly what is in it.
steps: 1. Take everything out of your bag|2. Throw away any rubbish|3. Put anything that does not belong in a bag back where it lives|4. Check what school things should be in there|5. Pack it back neatly with the things you need most accessible
success: Your bag is clean, tidy and everything in it is meant to be there

title: Digital Tidy-Up
description: Organise the files and photos on your device.
steps: 1. Open your files or photos app|2. Delete anything you no longer need|3. Create folders for different types of things — school, personal, photos|4. Move files into the right folder|5. Take a screenshot of what it looks like when organised
goal: Digital organisation and good habits around technology
success: Your device has clearly labelled folders and no loose files on the main screen

title: Set Up a Morning Checklist
description: Create a personal morning checklist to stick to your bedroom door.
steps: 1. Think about everything you need to do every morning|2. Write each step in order: wake up, drink water, wash face, get dressed, eat breakfast, pack bag, leave on time|3. Decorate it if you like|4. Stick it somewhere visible — door, mirror, bedside
materials: paper, pen, tape or sticky tack
success: You have a finished morning checklist displayed where you will see it

title: Track Your Money
description: Write down everything you spend this week and what it was on.
steps: 1. Get a small notebook just for this|2. Write today's date|3. Every time you spend money this week, write down: what, how much, date|4. At the end of the week, add it all up|5. Look at what you spent most on|6. Notice if anything surprises you
success: You have a written record of every purchase this week with amounts

title: Mindful Morning Moment
description: Spend 2 minutes in quiet before your day starts, just breathing and noticing.
steps: 1. Before you check your phone or talk to anyone, find a quiet spot|2. Sit comfortably and close your eyes|3. Take 10 slow breaths, paying attention only to each breath|4. If thoughts come, just notice them and let them go|5. After 10 breaths, gently open your eyes
goal: Mindfulness, starting the day from a calm place
success: You spent 2 minutes in silence before doing anything else

title: Review Your Week on Friday
description: At the end of the school week, take 10 minutes to look back at what went well and what did not.
steps: 1. Get your planner or notebook|2. Look back at what was on this week|3. Write: what went well this week? What did not go well? What do I want to do differently next week?|4. Write at least one sentence for each question|5. Close the notebook knowing you have prepared for next week
success: You have written at least one sentence answering each of the three reflection questions

title: Anger Cool-Down Routine
description: When you feel angry, use a set sequence to calm down before responding.
steps: 1. Notice anger rising — feel it in your body (jaw tight? fists clenched? face hot?)|2. Leave the situation if possible — go to a different room or step outside|3. Take 5 big breaths, breathing out longer than you breathe in|4. Walk for 2 minutes or splash cold water on your face|5. Only return and respond once your body feels calmer
success: You used the full cool-down routine before responding to a situation that made you angry

title: Compliment Three People Today
description: Give three genuine, specific compliments today.
steps: 1. Think of three people in your life|2. For each person, think of something genuine and specific you appreciate — not just you look nice but I really liked how you explained that yesterday|3. Tell each person their compliment at a natural moment in conversation|4. Notice how they respond
goal: Generosity, noticing others, building a positive habit
success: You gave three genuine, specific compliments to three different people

title: Practise Saying No Kindly
description: Practise turning down a request in a way that is kind but clear.
steps: 1. Think of a situation this week where you said yes to something when you wanted to say no|2. Write down what happened and how it felt|3. Write an alternative response — one that is honest but kind, for example I am sorry I cannot this time or I need some time to myself today|4. Practise saying it out loud three times
success: You have written and practised out loud a kind but clear refusal that does not over-explain or apologise excessively

title: Be the Includer
description: Today, actively include someone who seems left out.
steps: 1. Look around in class, at break, at lunch or at an activity|2. Notice if anyone is on their own who does not seem to want to be|3. Go over and include them — ask a question, invite them to join, start a conversation|4. Keep the conversation going for at least a few minutes|5. Reflect on how it felt
success: You made a genuine effort to include someone who was on their own

title: Put Your Phone Away During a Meal
description: Eat one full meal today with your phone in another room and have a real conversation.
steps: 1. Before sitting down to eat, put your phone in another room|2. Sit at a table with whoever is eating with you|3. Have a real conversation — ask them something, share something from your day|4. Stay phone-free for the whole meal|5. Put the phone away again afterward if it was only out briefly
goal: Being present, real connection, managing phone habits
success: You ate a full meal without your phone and had a real conversation

title: No-Complaint Hour
description: Go one full hour without complaining about anything.
steps: 1. Choose a time period — after school or at home in the evening|2. Set a timer for 60 minutes|3. Every time you notice a complaint forming, let it go or reframe it into something neutral|4. If you slip up, reset the timer and try again|5. At the end, notice how the hour felt compared to normal
goal: Positive thinking, impulse control, managing negativity
success: You went a full uninterrupted hour without complaining out loud

title: Self-Care Basket
description: Create a small collection of things that help you feel better when you are having a hard day.
steps: 1. Get a box, basket or bag|2. Choose 4–6 things that genuinely help you feel calm or better — a note from someone kind, a small toy, a list of things you love, headphones, a scented candle (with adult permission), a favourite book|3. Write on a piece of paper: When I feel bad, I will open this|4. Put it somewhere easy to reach|5. Do not use it unless you actually need it
success: You have a basket with at least four items and a note explaining when to use it

title: Cold Water Face Splash
description: Splash cold water on your face every morning as part of your wake-up routine.
steps: 1. Go to the bathroom sink|2. Turn the cold tap on|3. Splash cold water on your face 5–10 times|4. Pat your face dry with a towel|5. Notice how much more awake you feel
goal: Physical alertness, building a morning habit
success: You splashed cold water on your face for at least 5 splashes

title: Teach Someone What You Learned
description: Explain something you learned at school today to another person.
steps: 1. Think of one thing you learned or read about at school today|2. Find someone to tell — a parent, sibling, friend|3. Explain it in your own words — do not read from a book|4. Answer any questions they ask if you can|5. Notice how well you actually understood it
goal: Deep learning, verbal communication, checking your own understanding
success: You explained one thing from school today in your own words to another person

title: Evening Reset Routine
description: Do a full reset of your bedroom and school area at the end of every day.
steps: 1. Tidy your desk or work area|2. Put any clothes off the floor away|3. Check your school bag is packed|4. Put your phone to charge outside your bedroom|5. Write one sentence in your journal about today — just one|6. Read for 10 minutes if possible before sleeping
success: All five steps are done before you get into bed

title: Break a Big Task Into Steps
description: Take something that feels overwhelming and write it out as small steps.
steps: 1. Think of a task that feels too big or scary to start|2. Write it at the top of a page|3. Break it into the smallest possible steps you can imagine|4. Aim for at least 8 steps even if some feel tiny|5. Do the first step right now — it only needs to take 2 minutes
success: You have a list of at least 8 steps for one big task and you have done step 1

title: Time a Task Before You Do It
description: Before starting a task, guess how long it will take. Then time yourself and compare.
steps: 1. Choose a task you need to do|2. Write down your guess: I think this will take ___ minutes|3. Set a timer when you start|4. Stop the timer when completely finished|5. Compare your guess to the real time|6. Write one sentence about what you noticed
success: You completed a task and compared your estimate to the actual time with a written observation

title: Write a 30-Day Goal
description: Set one small goal to work toward over the next 30 days.
steps: 1. Think about one skill, habit or achievement you would like to work toward|2. Write it as a specific, measurable goal — not I want to be better but I will read for 10 minutes every night for 30 days|3. Write why this goal matters to you|4. Write what you will do every day to work toward it|5. Put the paper somewhere visible
success: You have a written 30-day goal with a specific daily action and a reason

title: Review a Past Goal
description: Look back at a goal you set before and honestly evaluate how it went.
steps: 1. Find a goal you set previously — it could be written down or just remembered|2. Ask yourself: did I achieve it?|3. If yes: write what helped you succeed|4. If no: write honestly why — were the steps too big? Did you lose motivation? Did life change?|5. Write what you would do differently
success: You have an honest written evaluation of a past goal with specific reasons for the outcome

title: Check In With Your Sleep
description: For one week, note the time you went to sleep and the time you woke up each morning.
steps: 1. Get a small notebook|2. Each morning this week, write: date, time I went to sleep, time I woke up, how I feel (1–5)|3. At the end of the week, look at the data|4. Notice: do you feel better on more-sleep nights?|5. Write one observation
goal: Sleep awareness, understanding your own patterns
success: You have a completed sleep log for 7 consecutive days with an honest observation at the end

title: Hydration Check
description: Track how much water you drink in a day.
steps: 1. Get a water bottle with a clear capacity|2. Starting from when you wake up, track each time you refill or drink|3. Aim for at least 6 glasses or 1.5 litres during the day|4. At the end of the day, write down approximately how much you drank|5. Notice if you felt different on a good-hydration day
success: You tracked your water intake across a full day and reached at least 6 glasses

title: Cook or Prepare One Meal
description: Independently prepare a simple, healthy snack or meal for yourself.
steps: 1. Choose something simple that is appropriate for your age and skills — toast with toppings, chopped fruit and yoghurt, a sandwich, scrambled eggs with adult supervision if needed|2. Gather everything you need|3. Prepare it step by step|4. Eat and enjoy it|5. Wash up the equipment you used
materials: ingredients and equipment for chosen food
success: You prepared and ate a complete food item and washed up afterward

title: No-Snooze Week
description: Commit to getting up at your first alarm for a full school week without hitting snooze.
steps: 1. Set your alarm for the time you genuinely need to get up|2. When it goes off, put both feet on the floor immediately|3. Do not lie back down|4. Do your morning routine straight away|5. At the end of each morning, write: got up first alarm yes/no
materials: alarm clock or phone (used for alarm only), notebook
success: You got up on the first alarm for 5 consecutive school days

title: Write a Proper To-Do List
description: Write a task list that actually helps you get things done.
steps: 1. Get a piece of paper or notebook|2. Write every task you need to do at the top|3. Mark each task: must do today / would be good to do / can wait|4. Star the single most important task|5. Do the starred task first before anything else
success: You have a written list with every task categorised and you have started the starred item

title: Practise Entering a Room Politely
description: Practise walking into a room where people are talking or working without disrupting them.
steps: 1. Before entering, listen for a moment — is a conversation happening? Is someone concentrating?|2. Enter quietly without slamming the door|3. Wait for a natural pause before speaking|4. Make eye contact and speak at a normal volume|5. Reflect: how was your entry compared to usual?
success: You entered a room without disrupting an ongoing conversation or activity

title: Table Manners Practice Meal
description: At one meal today, practise every table manner you know.
steps: 1. Sit up straight at the table|2. Wait until everyone is served before starting|3. Eat with your mouth closed|4. Do not speak with food in your mouth|5. Put your phone away|6. Say please and thank you|7. At the end, take your plate to the kitchen
goal: Table manners, social skills, mealtime behaviour
success: You completed a full meal practising all six manners — check each one at the end

title: Practise Making and Receiving Eye Contact
description: Spend one day consciously making eye contact when talking to and being talked to.
steps: 1. In every conversation today, make soft eye contact when you are listening|2. Do not stare — it is okay to look away briefly but keep returning|3. When someone is talking to you, put away any device and look at them|4. At the end of the day, notice: did people seem to respond to you differently?
success: You made conscious eye contact in at least 4 conversations during the day

title: Queue Patiently
description: Practise waiting in a queue without complaining, checking your phone or pushing.
steps: 1. The next time you are in a queue — shops, school, anywhere|2. Do not check your phone|3. Do not sigh loudly or complain|4. Find something to notice or think about|5. When you reach the front, be ready and polite|6. Reflect: how did it feel to wait patiently?
success: You waited in a queue without using your phone or complaining

title: Disagree Respectfully
description: Practise disagreeing with someone without being rude or dismissive.
steps: 1. Think of a situation where you disagreed with someone recently|2. Write what you actually said|3. Rewrite it using this structure: I understand what you are saying. I see it differently because [your reason]. Could we think about it another way?|4. Practise saying this out loud|5. Use it the next time you disagree
success: You have written and practised a respectful disagreement response that acknowledges the other person

title: Screen Time Awareness Day
description: Track exactly how long you spend on screens today and what you used them for.
steps: 1. Write down the time every time you pick up a phone, tablet or sit at a computer|2. Write what you were doing on each device|3. Add up the total screen time at the end of the day|4. Write whether the time felt well-used or wasted|5. Set one intention for tomorrow based on what you noticed
goal: Digital awareness, self-monitoring, intentional use of technology
success: You have a full record of today's screen time with an honest reflection and one intention for tomorrow

title: Read and Summarise
description: Read a chapter or article and then summarise it in your own words.
steps: 1. Choose a chapter from a book or an article about something you are curious about|2. Read it fully without stopping|3. Put it away|4. Write a 3–5 sentence summary in your own words without looking at the original|5. Read back what you wrote
success: You have a 3–5 sentence summary written entirely in your own words without looking at the source

title: Learn Something New for 10 Minutes
description: Choose something you are curious about and spend 10 minutes learning about it.
steps: 1. Think of something you have always wanted to know more about — an animal, a country, a sport, a skill|2. Find a good source — a book, encyclopedia, reliable website|3. Spend exactly 10 minutes reading or watching about it|4. Write 3 things you learned|5. Share one of them with someone|6. Could be anything from how earthquakes work to how to draw animals
materials: book, library book, or trusted website
success: You wrote down 3 new things you learned and shared one with another person

title: Finish What You Started
description: Today, finish every task you start before moving on to the next thing.
steps: 1. Before you begin anything, ask: can I finish this before I do something else?|2. If yes, do it completely|3. Do not switch to something else before it is done|4. Put a small tick or mark every time you finish something fully|5. At the end of the day, count your ticks
success: You have a list of completed tasks from today and none have been left half-done

title: Visualise Success
description: Spend 5 minutes imagining yourself achieving a goal.
steps: 1. Choose one goal you are working toward|2. Find a comfortable quiet place|3. Close your eyes and imagine yourself completing or achieving that goal in detail — what does it look like? Feel like? Who is around you? What do you say or do?|4. Hold the image for the full 5 minutes, returning to it when your mind wanders|5. Open your eyes and write one sentence about what you imagined
goal: Goal motivation, positive thinking, mental practice
success: You spent the full 5 minutes visualising without giving up or opening your eyes early

title: Notice What Makes You Feel Good
description: Make a list of everything that genuinely lifts your mood.
steps: 1. Get a notebook|2. Think back over the last few weeks|3. Write everything that made you feel good — even small things like a specific song, a smell, a food, a place, a person, a type of activity|4. Try to write at least 10 things|5. Put a star next to the 3 that work best for you|6. Keep this list somewhere you can find it when you are having a hard day
goal: Self-awareness, emotional regulation tool, positive coping strategies
success: You have a list of at least 10 things with 3 starred as most effective

title: Cold Shower or Cold Rinse
description: End your shower with 30 seconds of cold water for energy and alertness.
steps: 1. Take your normal shower|2. At the end, turn the temperature to cold|3. Stay under for 30 seconds — breathe slowly, do not panic|4. Turn the shower off|5. Notice how awake and energised you feel compared to most mornings
success: You completed 30 seconds of cold water at the end of your shower

title: Ask Someone How They Really Are
description: Today, ask someone how they are — and actually listen to the answer.
steps: 1. Choose someone you care about|2. Ask: how are you really doing lately?|3. Listen without interrupting|4. Ask one follow-up question based on what they said|5. Do not share your own situation unless they ask|6. Reflect afterward: what did you learn about them?
success: You had a genuine conversation about how someone is really doing and asked a real follow-up question

title: Two-Minute Rule
description: If a task takes less than two minutes, do it immediately without adding it to a list.
steps: 1. Pay attention today to small tasks that come up|2. Every time you notice something small that needs doing — replying to a message, washing a cup, putting something away — ask: will this take under two minutes?|3. If yes, do it immediately|4. At the end of the day, notice how clear your space and to-do list feel
goal: Productivity, reducing backlog, building an action habit
success: You completed all small tasks immediately throughout the day rather than deferring them

title: Create a Study Schedule
description: Write a weekly study schedule showing when you will do each subject.
steps: 1. Look at what homework or study you have this week|2. Get a blank weekly timetable or draw one|3. Assign each subject or piece of work to a specific time slot|4. Be realistic — do not fill every hour|5. Include breaks and end times|6. Stick to the schedule for at least two days
success: You have a written schedule with realistic time blocks for at least 3 subjects covering the current week

title: Draw or Colour Something
description: Spend 15 minutes drawing, colouring or creating something just for yourself.
steps: 1. Get paper and pens, pencils or art supplies|2. Choose something to draw or create — it does not need to be good|3. Spend 15 minutes creating without looking at your phone|4. You do not need to show it to anyone|5. Notice how you feel during and after
success: You spent 15 minutes creating without stopping or checking your phone

title: Speak in a Full Sentence
description: Practise giving full, clear answers instead of one-word replies.
steps: 1. Today, notice every time someone asks you a question|2. Answer in a full sentence, not just fine or yes or no|3. Include at least one specific detail — instead of good add something like it was good because we had PE|4. Make eye contact when you respond|5. At the end of the day, notice whether people seemed more interested in talking to you
success: You answered in full sentences at least 5 times today, each with a specific detail

title: Write a Letter to Your Future Self
description: Write a letter to yourself to read in one year's time.
steps: 1. Get several sheets of paper|2. Write the date and Dear [your name]|3. Write about who you are right now — what you care about, what you are working on, what you are worried about, what you hope for|4. Write what you hope to have achieved or changed by the time you read this|5. Seal the letter in an envelope, write the date to open it, and put it somewhere safe
success: You have written and sealed a letter to your future self with at least 4 paragraphs covering who you are now and what you hope for

title: No Social Media or News for a Day
description: Spend a full day without social media, news apps or YouTube and notice how it feels.
steps: 1. Decide in advance: no social media, news or YouTube for today|2. If you need to use your phone, use it only for calls, texts and school-related things|3. Replace that time with something real — exercise, reading, talking, creating, going outside|4. At the end of the day, write: how did I feel? What did I miss? What did I gain?
success: You went a full day without social media and wrote a genuine reflection about how it felt

title: Personal Hygiene Checklist
description: Work through a full personal hygiene routine completely on your own.
steps: 1. Shower or wash properly — hair, body, face|2. Brush teeth for 2 full minutes, top and bottom, all areas|3. Use deodorant|4. Put on clean underwear and clean clothes|5. Check your nails — trim if needed|6. Comb or brush your hair
materials: shower or bath, toothbrush, toothpaste, deodorant, clean clothes, nail scissors
success: All six steps are completed fully and independently without reminders

title: Reflect on a Mistake Without Blame
description: Think about a mistake you made and learn from it rather than feeling bad about it.
steps: 1. Think of a mistake you made recently — something that went wrong or something you wish you had done differently|2. Write: what happened?|3. Write: what could I have done differently?|4. Write: what will I do next time?|5. End with: that is okay. I have learned something.
success: You have written all three reflection steps plus the closing affirmation without giving up on the exercise
